Article Title: Reducing Russian crude imports: India wants US to allow oil from Iran, Venezuela; 25% penal tariffs in focus
Article Text:
Since the Russia-Ukraine conflict began in 2022, India has significantly increased its crude oil imports from Russia. (AI image)

Despite Trump 'Economic Sanctions', India's Russian Oil Flow Ramped Up As U.S Trade Talks Resume

India’s Crude Oil Trade with Russia

Who bought Russia's fossil fuels after EU bans





India, faced with 25% additional penal tariffs for its crude trade with Russia, has reportedly asked the US to allow oil imports from Iran and Venezuela.Following international sanctions due to the Ukraine conflict, Russia began offering its oil at reduced prices. With India importing nearly 90% of its oil requirements, the cost-effective Russian supplies have helped reduce its import expenses. Similar price advantages could be available from Iranian and Venezuelan supplies.According to a Bloomberg report, Indian officials, during their US visit this week, reiterated their stance to the Trump administration regarding oil imports. They suggested that any substantial decrease in Russian oil purchases by Indian refiners would necessitate Washington's approval for crude imports from Iran and Venezuela, both currently under sanctions, the report said.During the discussions with Trump officials, the visiting delegation underscored their position, a source was quoted as saying. The Indian officials emphasised that restricting their refiners' access to oil from Russia, Iran and Venezuela simultaneously could potentially trigger a worldwide price surge, as confirmed by individuals familiar with the ongoing negotiations.Indian officials visited the United States for discussions following Washington's implementation of 50% tariffs on India.The country has continued importing Russian crude, though at reduced volumes, despite these penalties.During his visit to New York, Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal indicated India’s intention to enhance its US oil and gas procurement, stating that "our energy security goals will have a very high element of US involvement".Since the Russia-Ukraine conflict began in 2022, India has significantly increased its crude oil imports from Russia.Finland's Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA) data shows India purchased Russian oil worth ₹132 billion (about ₹13.39 lakh crore) from early 2022. This accounts for 20% of Russia's overall oil export revenue of ₹640 billion during this timeframe.Despite Western opposition, Russian oil continues to be available in global markets without complete restrictions, allowing countries such as India and China to obtain it at discounted rates.India's additional purchases included Russian coal valued at ₹16 billion, taking its total fossil fuel imports from Russia to ₹148 billion. Russia's total earnings from oil, gas, and coal exports since the conflict began amounted to ₹931 billion.CREA data indicates that while Chinese Russian oil imports were ₹193 billion, India's purchases exceeded both the EU's ₹105 billion and Turkiye's ₹71 billion.China ranked as Russia's top customer with total fossil fuel imports of ₹268 billion, with the EU following at ₹213 billion, India at ₹148 billion, and Turkiye at ₹111 billion.
Article Summary: Since the Russia-Ukraine conflict began in 2022, India has significantly increased its crude oil imports from Russia. Indian officials visited the United States for discussions following Washington's implementation of 50% tariffs on India. The Indian officials emphasised that restricting their refiners' access to oil from Russia, Iran and Venezuela simultaneously could potentially trigger a worldwide price surge.

Article Title: Rare earth elements: President Murmu says India must become self-reliant; ‘important for ensuring national security’
Article Text: President Droupadi Murmu on Friday highlighted the need for India to become self-reliant in producing rare earth elements, saying this is vital in the current geopolitical climate and will play a key role in the country’s journey towards becoming a developed nation.Speaking at the National Geoscience Awards 2024, she further added that it would ensure the security of the country.The President explained that these minerals are not considered rare because of their limited supply, but because the process of identifying them is highly complex. She also highlighted that developing homegrown techniques would be crucial in overcoming this challenge.President Murmu pointed out that rare earth elements are central to the technologies shaping the modern world, from artificial intelligence and semiconductors to clean energy solutions.The rare earth elements or REEs are a group of 17 chemically alike metallic elements which are of vital importance to the development of modern technologies including smartphones, electric vehicles, renewable energy systems and wind turbines.She said the mines ministry is working to ensure sustainability and innovation in the sector, with projects that include AI- and drone-based surveys and efforts to extract valuable materials from mine tailings.The President also used the occasion to highlight the need for better disaster preparedness. Referring to the heavy damage caused this year by cloudbursts and landslides, she urged scientists to strengthen research into floods, landslides, earthquakes and tsunamis."It is my appeal to the geoscientist community to pay more attention on the research of natural calamities like flood, landslide, earthquake, and tsunami," she said, adding that new technologies should be developed to ensure timely alerts reach the public.Instituted in 1966 by the mines ministry and earlier known as the National Mineral Awards, the National Geoscience Awards remain one of the country’s most prestigious honours in the geoscience field.
Article Summary: President Droupadi Murmu highlighted the need for India to become self-reliant in producing rare earth elements. She further added that it would ensure the security of the country. Rare earth elements are central to the technologies shaping the modern world, from artificial intelligence and semiconductors to clean energy solutions.

Article Title: Trump’s 100% tariffs on pharma: Sun Pharma, Biocon, Cipla & other pharmaceutical stocks tank; jitters on D-Street
Article Text:
Several prominent Indian pharmaceutical firms, including Sun Pharma, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories, Cipla, Lupin, Aurobindo Pharma, and Zydus Lifesciences, maintain substantial export operations to the USA. (AI image)

After 50% Tariff, Donald Trump Hits India With 100% Tax on Medicines, Targets Pharma Companies



Trump Tariff Uncertainties Loom





Pharma stocks hit by Trump’s tariffs: Pharmaceutical stocks declined sharply by up to 5% on Friday, September 26, following US President Donald Trump's declaration of imposing 100% tariffs on branded and patent-protected medicines. Sun Pharma experienced the steepest decline, touching its yearly low at Rs 1,547, showing a 5% reduction from its last closing price. Biocon witnessed a 3.3% fall to Rs 344, whilst Zydus Lifesciences declined by 2.8%, settling at Rs 990.Aurobindo Pharma decreased by 2.4% to Rs 1,070, and Dr. Reddy's registered a 2.3% decline to Rs 1,245.30. Both Lupin and Cipla saw a 2% reduction, ending at Rs 1,923.30 and Rs 1,480, respectively. Torrent Pharma showed the smallest decline of 1.5%, reaching Rs 3,480.65.At approximately 9:30 am, the Nifty Pharma index showed a reduction of 2.54%.As per the announcement on Truth Social platform, Trump declared that from October 1, all imported branded or patented medicines to the United States would face a 100% tariff, unless manufacturers establish production facilities within the country.Several prominent Indian pharmaceutical firms, including Sun Pharma, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories, Cipla, Lupin, Aurobindo Pharma, and Zydus Lifesciences, maintain substantial export operations to the USA.Additional pharmaceutical entities such as Syngene, Gland Pharma, Biocon, and Piramal Pharma also generate considerable revenue from the American market, particularly through generics, speciality medications, and biosimilars.The announcement specifies that exemptions would be granted solely to companies that have initiated construction or are actively developing pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities in the U.S. This policy aims to strengthen domestic production whilst reducing dependence on international sources for premium, patent-protected medications."There will, therefore, be no Tariff on these Pharmaceutical Products if construction has started," the post clarified, defining "IS BUILDING" as having commenced physical construction or site development.The declaration is likely to affect Indian pharmaceutical companies that presently produce their branded medicines abroad for the American market. Share prices of businesses with substantial US export presence will be under close observation, alongside domestic medicine producers who could gain from possible alterations in worldwide supply networks.
Article Summary: US President Donald Trump's declaration of imposing 100% tariffs on branded and patent-protected medicines. From October 1, all imported branded or patented medicines to the United States would face a 100% tariff, unless manufacturers establish production facilities within the country.

Article Title: SpiceJet expands fleet! Airbus A340 to join by September-end; 18 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft planned from this year
Article Text:
SpiceJet representative image

Expansion plans: Second A340 and Boeing 737 MAX jets







Gurugram-based low-cost carrier SpiceJet has announced the lease of a wide-body Airbus A340 aircraft, marking a key step in its fleet expansion strategy. The aircraft is expected to arrive in India later this month and begin operations in the first week of October, subject to regulatory approvals.According to the airline, the Airbus A340 will initially operate on a wet lease model before transitioning to a damp lease, giving the carrier more operational flexibility and cost savings."We are thrilled to introduce the Airbus A340 into our fleet as part of our ongoing efforts to enhance our service offerings and expand our domestic and international network," said SpiceJet chief business officer Debojo Maharshi.He added that the aircraft’s induction marked the beginning of one of the airline’s most ambitious growth phases. "This aircraft will allow us to tap into new markets and expand our international footprint," Maharshi said, as quoted by ANI.SpiceJet confirmed it is in advanced talks to lease a second Airbus A340, strengthening its wide-body capacity. The airline also highlighted plans to induct 18 Boeing 737 aircraft, including four Boeing 737 MAX jets, with deliveries starting in October 2025."With another A340 under negotiation and 18 Boeing 737 aircraft joining our fleet soon, SpiceJet is poised for one of its most ambitious growth phases," Maharshi noted.The induction of the Airbus A340 is aimed at boosting capacity to meet rising passenger demand and enhancing connectivity across SpiceJet’s domestic and international network. With new aircraft joining the fleet, the airline said it is positioning itself for sustained growth in both capacity and connectivity, reported ANI.SpiceJet is currently India’s fourth-largest airline by domestic passenger market share, carrying 4% as of May 2025. The airline operates flights to 73 destinations, including 60 within India and 13 international routes, from its hubs in Delhi and Hyderabad.
Article Summary: SpiceJet announces lease of wide-body Airbus A340 aircraft. The aircraft is expected to arrive in India later this month and begin operations in the first week of October. The airline is also in advanced talks to lease a second A340 and 18 Boeing 737 aircraft.

Article Title: Deposit claims up to Rs 15L get easier for kin of deceased
Article Text: MUMBAI: RBI has issued new rules on Friday that in the event of a bank customer's death, deposits of up to Rs 15 lakh can be claimed by their nominees through a simplified process. For co-operative banks, the limit has been set at Rs 5 lakh.RBI's new norms have standardised procedures across banks for deposits, safe deposit lockers, and articles in safe custody. The framework replaces earlier circulars and introduces uniform documentation, thresholds, and timelines. The new rules have to be implemented by the end of the current fiscal.For deposits without a nominee, survivorship clause, or will - and where there is no court order or contesting claim - banks must settle claims on submission of a claim form, death certificate, valid ID of the claimant, an indemnity bond, and, if applicable, a letter of disclaimer from other heirs. A legal heir certificate or a declaration by an independent person acceptable to the bank is also required. Banks cannot demand a third-party surety bond for claims within the threshold.RBI has fixed a 15-day deadline for banks to settle deposit claims after receiving all documents.For lockers and safe custody articles, banks must contact claimants and set an inventory date within 15 days. Delays will attract penalties - interest at bank rate plus 4% per annum for deposits, and Rs 5,000 per day for lockers and safe custody items.Banks have been directed to implement the new rules at the earliest, and no later than March 31, 2026.
Article Summary: RBI's new norms have standardised procedures across banks for deposits, safe deposit lockers, and articles in safe custody. Banks must settle claims on submission of a claim form, death certificate, valid ID of the claimant, an indemnity bond, and, if applicable, a letter of disclaimer from other heirs.

Article Title: ‘Corrupt and totally Trump deranged’: US President urges Microsoft to sack Lisa Monaco; calls her ‘menace’ to security
Article Text:
Donald Trump urges Microsoft to sack Lisa Monaco (Picture credit: AP, US department of justice)





US President Donald Trump on Friday publicly demanded that Microsoft dismiss Lisa Monaco, the company’s president of global affairs and a former top official in Democratic administrations.In a lengthy Truth Social post, Trump claimed ‘corrupt and totally Trump deranged’ Monaco posed risks to national security because of her past government roles. “She is a menace to US National Security, especially given the major contracts that Microsoft has with the United States Government,” Trump wrote.“Because of Monaco’s many wrongful acts, the US Government recently stripped her of all Security Clearances, took away all of her access to National Security Intelligence, and banned her from all Federal Properties.”Trump added that “it is my opinion that Microsoft should immediately terminate the employment of Lisa Monaco.”According to news agency Reuters, Monaco began working at Microsoft in July, taking charge of the firm’s global engagement with governments. Her LinkedIn profile confirms the appointment.She previously served as a national security aide under Barack Obama , helped coordinate the justice department’s response to the January 6 Capitol attack, and was deputy attorney general during Joe Biden ’s administration.Trump linked his demand to Monaco’s role in the Biden justice department, which pursued legal cases against him. He argued that her senior position at Microsoft, with access to sensitive information, was “unacceptable.”The criticism comes after former FBI director James Comey, a longtime Trump adversary, was indicted on obstruction and perjury charges.Trump has said he expects “others” to face prosecution, according to Reuters.The attack on Monaco highlights Trump’s broader pattern of targeting perceived political enemies. Since returning to the White House in January, he has pushed for charges against several figures, including former national security adviser John Bolton and Democratic Senator Adam Schiff, and has exerted pressure on institutions ranging from law firms to universities.The president’s interventions have also extended into corporate America. His administration previously demanded the resignation of Intel’s chief executive, pressed Disney’s ABC over comedian Jimmy Kimmel’s show, and influenced decisions at other major firms.Meanwhile, Microsoft continues to navigate its relationship with the administration. Earlier this month, CEO Satya Nadella attended a White House dinner with Trump and other technology leaders.The company has also been under scrutiny for its contracts with US agencies and, separately, for restricting certain cloud services to a unit of the Israeli military following a review of alleged surveillance practices, reported CNBC.
Article Summary: Lisa Monaco is Microsoft's president of global affairs. She previously served as a national security aide under Barack Obama. She was deputy attorney general during Joe Biden's administration. Trump claims Monaco posed risks to national security because of her past government roles.

Article Title: Tata Capital's stock market debut: IPO launch set for October 6; what we know

Tata Capital is set to launch its initial public offering ( IPO ) on October 6, featuring fresh shares and an offer for sale, as reported by Reuters. Article Title: Risks appear manageable for now: Finmin
Article Text: NEW DELHI: There will be an impact on export sectors with spillover risk to domestic employment, income and consumption if tariff uncertainties persist, a finance ministry report said, adding, govt's reform agenda is expected to cushion economy against adverse effects of trade disruptions."Newer markets will take time to mature and contribute to export growth as established markets have. The decision by the US govt to impose a fee on new H-1B visa-seekers is a reminder of the risks of trade uncertainties affecting the hitherto unaffected services sector," said the finance ministry's monthly report for Aug."For now, risks appear manageable, but they are there," said the report. It said regulatory reform and infrastructure development will be key to sustaining growth momentum."States will do well to leverage cooperative federalism and contribute to this effort by pursuing state-level deregulation, thereby putting India's economy on a higher growth trajectory," said the report. It said the near-term outlook is characterised by steady, reform-driven growth rooted in macro discipline and adaptive economic diplomacy, with vigilance warranted against external shocks and global market volatility. The report said that taking advantage of the strong monsoon and even excess rains, India must invest in water storage, deepening, desilting, and rejuvenating water bodies.
Article Summary: There will be an impact on export sectors with spillover risk to domestic employment, income and consumption if tariff uncertainties persist, finance ministry report says. Newer markets will take time to mature and contribute to export growth as established markets have, it says. It said regulatory reform and infrastructure development will be key to sustaining growth momentum.

Article Title: Not a med emergency: Generic pharma cos spared from harm
Article Text: NEW DELHI/HYDERABAD: India's generic companies are likely to continue in business-as-usual mode as US President Donald Trump's 100% levy on pharmaceuticals is targeted at branded and patented medicines, but it may also prompt some of them to rethink their playbook.Industry experts told TOI that the country's largest drugmaker Sun Pharma could face headwinds as its drug sales in US totalled $1.1 billion in FY25 (in which patented drugs have a significant portion), which was around 17% of its total revenue. Analysts added that branded biosimilars manufactured by companies, including Biocon, may be affected.Companies with manufacturing bases in US - including Sun Pharma, Dr Reddy's and Cipla - could cushion the blow by shifting production of higher-value specialty and niche drugs from India to the American facilities, said experts. Over time, the move could drive companies to diversify export markets, recalibrate global strategies, shift to contract manufacturing in the US and set up manufacturing bases there to safeguard access to the world's most lucrative market."At this point, we do not see an impact," Dr Reddy's co-chairman & MD G V Prasad said, adding, the company also does not see expanding its manufacturing footprint in the US immediately."Domestic companies are examining all options to mitigate risk, ranging from setting up manufacturing facilities in the US to shifting production of high-value specialty drugs, niche therapies and peptides to existing plants," an industry expert said. India's pharma exports to the US were close to $10 billion last year and it serviced around 35% of US prescriptions with affordable generics."India plays a vital role in US healthcare by ensuring a steady supply of affordable medicines. A majority of life-saving cardiac, diabetes and chronic medicines are supplied from India," said Indian Pharmaceutical Alliance secretary general Sudarshan Jain. Deepak Jotwani, VP & sector head, corporate ratings, Icra added, "Overall, this move by the US underscores the need for Indian pharma companies to diversify markets and innovate in complex generics and biosimilars to stay resilient in a changing global trade landscape. "Pharmexcil chairman Namit Joshi said most large Indian companies already operate manufacturing or repackaging units in US and are exploring further acquisitions. "India will need to reinforce its cost-efficiency advantage in bulk drugs and APIs, an area where the US is likely to favour India over other suppliers, and simultaneously invest in next-generation opportunities, such as complex generics, peptides and biosimilars. "The pharma sector is awaiting more clarity on the announcement as it did not specify whether speciality drugs, niche or complex generic drugs are under its ambit. However, a few experts said there was uncertainty over the definition of "branded" drugs. "If we take the terms branded and patented products at face value, Granules does not fall into either category," Granules India ED Priyanka Chigurupati said.
Article Summary: US President Donald Trump's 100% levy on pharmaceuticals is targeted at branded and patented medicines. Companies with manufacturing bases in US - including Sun Pharma, Dr Reddy's and Cipla - could cushion the blow by shifting production of higher-value specialty and niche drugs.

Article Title: Govt to borrow marginally less in H2 of FY26
Article Text: MUMBAI: Govt on Friday said it would borrow less through long-tenure bonds during the second half (Oct-March) of the current fiscal year compared to in the first half. This could aid transmission of RBI's rate cuts.Market analysts and investment managers said that along with cuts in GST and reduction in income tax, govt's decision to remain within the Budgeted borrowing limits shows its seriousness about adherence to fiscal prudence.Govt also said it would borrow a marginal Rs 5,000 crore lower than its estimates, taking the aggregate borrowing for H2FY26 to Rs 6.77 lakh crore. The total borrowing for FY26 has been pegged at Rs 14.72 lakh crore, Rs 10,000 crore less than the Budget estimate. "The borrowing calendar has been spread out till March which will address market fear about additional borrowing," said Ram Kamal Samanta of Star Union Dai-ichi Life Insurance. To borrow less through long-dated papers and more through short- and medium-tenure ones was one of the suggestions to the central bank from the debt market investors.
Article Summary: Market analysts and investment managers said that along with cuts in GST and reduction in income tax, govt's decision to remain within the Budgeted borrowing limits shows seriousness about adherence to fiscal prudence. To borrow less through long-dated papers and more through short- and medium-tenure ones was one of the suggestions to the central bank from the debt market investors.

Article Title: 'H-1B impact on remittances to be under $5bn'
Article Text:
US To Abandon H1-B Visa Lottery System, Trump Floats More Changes To Rules | Detailed Report





MUMBAI: The impact of restrictions on H-1B visas by the United States on remittances by overseas Indians would be within $5bn, according to a Barclays research report. The report also said that the rising trend of global capability centers (GCCs), which includes many US-headquartered firms, is here to stay and would strengthen further amid this likely H-1B overhaul, instead of acting as a drag on services exports.Earlier this month, US President Donald Trump announced two changes for the H-1B visas: a one-time $100,000 fee for new visas, and a wage-based selection process, which replaces the existing lottery-based selection system, favouring higher-skilled and higher-paid applicants by giving them multiple entries in the selection pool."The impact of these new rules, in terms of likely loss of jobs and dependent livelihoods cannot be discounted, but the effect via remittance is unlikely to breach $5bn (out of a total of $83bn). Other countries (Germany, Canada) have already started showing interest in attracting highly-skilled Indian talent and we expect some redistribution of movement over the medium term," said Barclays. The US accounts for 62% of India's IT and IT-enabled services exports, but industry growth has not been driven by US-based employment.
Article Summary: The impact of restrictions on H-1B visas by the United States on remittances by overseas Indians would be within $5bn, according to a Barclays research report. The report also said that the rising trend of global capability centers (GCCs), which includes many US-headquartered firms, is here to stay.

Article Title: Govt: India-US trade deal talks 'constructive'
Article Text:
Union Minister Piyush Goyal Eyes India-US Trade Deal By November Despite Donald Trump’s Tariff War





NEW DELHI: Government on Friday said that a team led by commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal , which met United States Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and ambassador designate Sergio Gor, held "constructive" talks on several aspects of the proposed trade deal."Both sides exchanged views on possible contours of the deal and it was decided to continue the engagements with a view to achieve early conclusion of a mutually beneficial trade agreement," an official statement said.Goyal's visit to Washington came after US President Donald Trump spoke in a conciliatory tone after talks for a trade deal came to a near standstill with a team from USTR also postponing the sixth round of talks in late Aug.India's oil purchases from Russia are at the centre of the impasse on the trade agreement, for which Trump and PM Narendra Modi had agreed to a Fall deadline, with New Delhi refusing to lower tariffs on farm products being the other contentious area.While govt has maintained that its red lines stay intact, Trump's pressure on Russian oil is seen to be thorny with Goyal publicly suggesting that India could increase its energy trade with the US in the coming years.
Article Summary: commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal met U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer and ambassador designate Sergio Gor. Goyal's visit to Washington came after US President Donald Trump spoke in a conciliatory tone after talks for a trade deal came to a near standstill.

Article Title: Bitter pill for Dalal Street: Sensex slides 733 pts
Article Text: MUMBAI: Fresh tariff-related jitters, weakness of the rupee and foreign fund selling pulled the sensex down by 733 points on Friday to 80,246 points, near its four-week low. As US President Donald Trump announced a fresh set of tariffs on imports of pharmaceutical products, most pharma stocks closed deep in the red.Nifty was down 236 points at 24,655 points. For both the indices, this was the sixth consecutive session of slide since their recent multi-month highs on Sept 18. The day's fall came on the back of strong selling by foreign portfolio investors with the day's net outflow at nearly Rs 5,700 crore, BSE data showed.According to Prashanth Tapse of Mehta Equities, risk-off sentiment continued in the market, reflecting in across-the-board selling. "Trump's decision to impose 100% tariff on branded & patented drugs further soured investors' sentiment. The market is already reeling under multiple pain-points like strong FII selling, US-India trade uncertainty, depreciating rupee and bullion's rising appeal, which is making investors jittery," Tapse wrote in a note to investors.At close of trading, investors were poorer by about Rs 6.8 lakh crore with BSE's market cap at Rs 450.6 lakh crore, data showed. Rupee closed slightly off its low at 88.72 against dollar.
Article Summary: Nifty was down 236 points at 24,655 points. For both the indices, this was the sixth consecutive session of slide since their recent multi-month highs on Sept 18. The day's fall came on the back of strong selling by foreign portfolio investors.

Article Title: Diwali cheer for Indian Railways employees! Cabinet approves productivity-linked bonus; Rs 1,865 crore payout
Article Text: The Union Cabinet on Wednesday approved payment of Productivity Linked Bonus (PLB) equivalent to 78 days’ wages to railway employees, with a financial implication of Rs 1,865.68 crore.The decision, taken at a meeting chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will benefit about 10.91 lakh non-gazetted employees of the Indian Railways. The bonus is paid annually before the Durga Puja and Dussehra holidays.According to the government, the maximum payable amount for each eligible employee has been fixed at Rs 17,951. The payment will cover various categories of staff, including track maintainers, loco pilots, train managers (guards), station masters, supervisors, technicians, technician helpers, pointsmen, ministerial staff, and other Group ‘C’ employees.The Cabinet Secretariat said the PLB scheme is designed to incentivise railway employees to improve efficiency and output. It added that the bonus is a recognition of their performance, particularly in a year when the Railways posted record operational numbers.In 2024-25, Indian Railways loaded a record 1,614.90 million tonnes of cargo and carried nearly 7.3 billion passengers, the government said.
Article Summary: The decision, taken at a meeting chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will benefit about 10.91 lakh non-gazetted employees. The bonus is paid annually before the Durga Puja and Dussehra holidays. The maximum payable amount for each eligible employee has been fixed at Rs 17,951.

Article Title: Algo diplomacy: How Xi Jinping used TikTok to court Donald Trump
Article Text:
AI image for representation only.

TL;DR: Driving the news

Big Win For Trump Amid Trade Faceoff With China, TikTok Algorithm Now Under American Oversight

Why it matters

The TikTok manoeuvre isn’t just about data privacy or algorithms. It’s about leverage the in ongoing US-China trade war.

Xi's quiet greenlight - not yet officially confirmed by Beijing - is part of a larger effort to reset US-China ties on China’s terms. And Trump, who once threatened to ban the app outright, now gets to tout himself as the man who saved TikTok and satisfied national security hawks.

As per a New York Times report, at its core, this is a story about how Xi Jinping turned a tech headache into a diplomatic lever, and how Donald Trump transformed a national security threat into a personal political win.

Interestingly, both leaders are using TikTok - a wildly popular app among American youth - to serve entirely different agendas:

For Xi: TikTok is no longer Beijing’s tech crown jewel. It’s a bargaining chip. China now sees more value in trading it for potential relief on US tariffs, export restrictions on AI chips, and diplomatic breathing room around Taiwan.

TikTok is no longer Beijing’s tech crown jewel. It’s a bargaining chip. China now sees more value in trading it for potential relief on US tariffs, export restrictions on AI chips, and diplomatic breathing room around Taiwan. For Trump: TikTok is a campaign lifeline. He credits it for helping him reach young voters in 2024 and boasts 15 million followers on the platform. Now, he gets to claim he “saved TikTok,” appeased security hawks, and secured a deal that looks tough on China - without actually banning the app.

Now, he gets to claim he “saved TikTok,” appeased security hawks, and secured a deal that looks tough on China - without actually banning the app. The timing also matters:

Beijing is under pressure: With economic headwinds at home, mounting Western export controls, and a post-pandemic slowdown, China is recalibrating its tone with Washington.

The US is headed toward a tech decoupling cliff: The deal sets a precedent for how Chinese tech can (or can’t) operate inside the American ecosystem - especially around algorithms, user data, and influence risks.

Congress is watching: The deal's structure - a licensed algorithm, American-controlled board, Oracle oversight - could become a template or a cautionary tale.

"It’s not just about who owns the app," Jasmine Enberg of Emarketer told AP. "It’s about who controls the algorithm, the data, and ultimately, the narrative."

In short: This isn’t a tech transaction. It’s a calculated act of tech diplomacy - one that could shape the next phase of the US-China rivalry and redefine the limits of digital sovereignty.

The big picture

What’s in the deal:

ByteDance keeps under 20% ownership and one board seat in the new company, TikTok US.

Oracle and Silver Lake will lead the investor group, alongside Abu Dhabi’s MGX. Trump also name-checked Michael Dell and Rupert Murdoch as investors.

Oracle gets algorithm oversight. The TikTok algorithm will be licensed from ByteDance, retrained solely on US data, and supervised by “trusted” American partners.

Data storage stays in Oracle’s cloud, with no ByteDance access to US user info.

Between the lines

What they are saying

“Young people really wanted this to happen,” Trump said.

He also admitted he would make TikTok “100% MAGA” if he could - though he insists the new app will be fair to “every philosophy.”

“There’s much bigger fish to fry,” Yun Sun, the director of the China program at the Stimson Center in Washington, told the NYT. “If China can use these small concessions to trade for a positive atmosphere, better US-China relations, they will want to do it,” she said, referring to TikTok.

"It’s not just about who owns the app," Jasmine Enberg of Emarketer. "It’s about who controls the algorithm, the data, and ultimately, the narrative.

Bloomberg Opinion’s Catherine Thorbecke put it: “In China, ‘win-win’ means China wins twice.”

What’s next

The TikTok deal may be just Act I. Trump and Xi are expected to speak again soon - possibly setting up a summit next month during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in South Korea.

Such a sit-down would mark their first in-person meeting since Trump returned to the White House - and could shape the next phase of global tech, trade, and military diplomacy.

Xi reportedly wants to host Trump in Beijing - both for symbolism and control. China is wary of another diplomatic misfire, like Ukraine’s Zelensky being publicly scolded at the White House.

Congressional review: Lawmakers are not convinced this setup truly complies with the 2024 law. Republican Rep. John Moolenaar says he plans to “discuss these issues with the transaction parties.”

Beijing’s final word: China must still issue a license for the algorithm’s export - a critical step that could derail or delay implementation.

Tech decoupling accelerates: Even if the TikTok deal succeeds, the broader push to sever strategic tech ties with China continues - from semiconductors to AI models.





President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday endorsing a $14 billion deal that would spin off TikTok’s US operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance. The move aims to meet the legal requirement set by a 2024 law forcing ByteDance to divest or face a ban in the US.But the headline-grabbing deal is more than a tech breakup. It’s a strategic olive branch from China - and President Xi Jinping appears to be playing a long game.“I had a very good talk with President Xi,” Trump said from the Oval Office. “We talked about TikTok and he gave us the go-ahead.”As the New York Times and Bloomberg have noted, China’s sudden acquiescence to a divestment it once labeled “robbery” has sparked questions about what’s being traded behind the scenes - and whether the most valuable export here isn’t TikTok’s algorithm, but goodwill from Beijing.The TikTok deal is part tech workaround, part geopolitical theater. On paper, it creates a US-based joint venture with a mostly American board and ownership structure. In reality, it’s a finely tuned diplomatic signal.JD Vance, Trump’s vice president, said the deal will put the new TikTok’s valuation at “roughly $14 billion” - a figure that Emarketer says aligns with its expected 2026 ad revenue.The algorithm - TikTok’s secret sauce - is at the center of the national security debate. While ByteDance keeps ownership, the new algorithm will be “rebuilt from the ground up” with Oracle's oversight, per US officials.“American investors will actually control the algorithm,” Vance emphasized.Still, skepticism remains: “Has ByteDance truly lost control?” asked Alan Rozenshtein of the University of Minnesota. “That’s far from clear.”Meanwhile, Beijing has been deliberately vague. No formal statement of approval. No confirmed export license. But state-run media described the deal as a “win-win,” and Xi’s silence suggests strategic consent - not surrender.(With inputs from agencies)

The deal sets a precedent for how Chinese tech can (or can’t) operate inside the American ecosystem - especially around algorithms, user data, and influence risks.

Article Title: US stocks: Wall Street inches higher after pharma tariff announcements; Dow over 300 points, S&P jumps 0.5%
Article Text: US stocks were trading in green on Friday, buoyed by a combination of factors including renewed hopes for more rate cuts and US President Donald Trump's announcing new tariffs, including a 100% import tax on foreign-made pharmaceutical drugs, starting next week.Dow Jones soared 369 points or 0.8% to reach 46,316 while Nasdaq jumped 71 points or 0.32%, trading at 22,455.S&P 500 also followed the trajectory, reaching 6,641, gaining 36 points or 0.56% at 7:20 PM IST.Investors were encouraged by a fresh inflation report, which suggested the Fed may have room to reduce rates further. Meanwhile, Trump’s new tariffs on pharmaceuticals, heavy trucks, and other imports created modest market reactions rather than major upheaval. US pharmaceutical companies rose slightly, while home-furnishing retailers slipped.Trump said on social media that foreign furniture and cabinetry makers were “flooding the United States” and tariffs were needed “for National Security and other reasons.” Shares of home-furnishing companies responded with losses: Wayfair and Williams-Sonoma fell nearly 3%, and RH dropped 5%.He also targeted foreign-made heavy trucks and parts, claiming they hurt US producers, though most trucks are either manufactured domestically or are US brands built in Canada or Mexico.Shares of Paccar, an American truck maker, jumped 6%.Dow component Boeing gained more than 3% after reports that federal safety regulators plan to ease oversight of the company.Investors are closely watching Friday’s US consumer spending data, which includes the Fed’s preferred inflation measure. Stocks have faced pressure this week after reports suggested the US economy may be stronger than expected. While that is good news for workers and jobseekers, it could limit the Fed’s ability to cut rates multiple times in the coming months.The Fed delivered its first rate cut of the year last week and had signalled further reductions through next year, which has helped drive US stocks to record highs since April. Easier rates boost economic growth and encourage investors to pay higher prices for stocks and other assets. The Fed will consider Friday’s inflation figures and labour market data when deciding its next move in late October.
Article Summary: Dow Jones soared 369 points or 0.8% to reach 46,316. Nasdaq jumped 71 points or0.32%, trading at 22,455. S&P 500 also followed the trajectory, reaching 6,641, gaining 36 points. Investors encouraged by fresh inflation report, which suggested the Fed may have room to reduce rates further.

Article Title: Turkish Airlines' landmark deal with Boeing: 75 Dreamliners eyed to modernise fleet; deliveries to span 2029–2034
Article Text:
Representative image





Turkish Airlines has announced plans to expand its fleet through a major deal with US-based Boeing. In a Friday filing to the Istanbul Stock Exchange, Turkey's national carrier said it aims to add up to 225 aircrafts.The airline said it will purchase 75 Boeing 787-9 and 787-10 Dreamliners, including 50 confirmed and 25 optional orders, with deliveries slated between 2029 and 2034. These long-haul aircraft are described as advanced and fuel-efficient, tailored for international routes, as reported by AP.In a parallel deal, Turkish Airlines finalised negotiations for 150 Boeing 737-8/10 MAX jets—100 confirmed and 50 optional orders—and will move ahead once engine supplier CFM International completes talks. The company is also negotiating with Rolls-Royce and GE Aerospace for engines, spare parts and maintenance services for the new fleet.The announcement came a day after Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan met US President Donald Trump in Washington. This marks a pivot from the earlier standing between the two nations as, during Trump’s first term, the US removed Turkey from the F-35 fighter jet program in 2019 over Ankara’s purchase of a Russian air defense system. However, Trump has recently signaled that Washington may soon lift its hold on sales of advanced fighter jets to the Nato ally.With this expansion, Turkish Airlines will continue to be one of the world’s largest flight networks, connecting Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas.
Article Summary: Turkey's national carrier said it aims to add up to 225 aircrafts. The airline said it will purchase 75 Boeing 787-9 and 777-10 Dreamliners. In a parallel deal, Turkish Airlines finalised negotiations for 150 Boeing 737-8/10 MAX jets.

Article Title: Asian drug market stocks slides: Trump’s 100% pharmaceutical tariffs shake market; broader impact on Japan likely minimal
Article Text:
Representative image





Asian drug stocks fell on Friday as investors reacted to US President Donald Trump ’s threat to impose 100% tariffs on imported branded pharmaceuticals starting October 1.Companies without existing US manufacturing plants could face the full impact, triggering declines across major drugmakers in South Korea, Japan, and Hong Kong.In South Korea, Samsung Biologics fell 1.6%, while SK Biopharmaceuticals slid 2.6%. Celltrion, which recently acquired ImClone Systems from Eli Lilly in the United States for $330 million, rose 1.3% after recouping earlier losses.In Japan, Sumitomo Pharma tumbled 4.3%, Otsuka Holdings dropped 3.5%, and Daiichi Sankyo lost 1.6%. Takeda added 0.2%, and Shionogi gained 1.3%.Meanwhile, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Biotech Index fell about 2.58%.Markets had already been braced for further tariffs and investigations by the US commerce department, said Carol Kong, economist and currency strategist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia in Sydney."The sectoral tariffs are here to stay because those have proven to be more legally sound than the emergency tariffs that the lower courts judged to be illegal," she said."Sectoral tariffs are going to push the US government's effective tariff rate a little bit high - it was about 10% in August, we expect the global effective tariff rate to edge further to about 18% in the coming months,” added Kong, as quoted by Reuters.Kong added that the broader impact on economies like Japan and Australia may be fairly limited.
Article Summary: Asian drug stocks fell on Friday as investors reacted to US President Donald Trump ’s threat to impose 100% tariffs on imported branded pharmaceuticals starting October 1.Companies without existing US manufacturing plants could face the full impact, triggering declines across major drugmakers in South Korea, Japan and Hong Kong.

Article Title: Asian markets drop as Trump unveils new tariffs: Pharmaceutical and Biotech stocks hit; oil, gold prices climb

Dollar strengthens, commodities rise







Asian markets opened cautiously on Friday after US President Donald Trump announced a fresh set of tariffs, while investors lowered expectations for significant Federal Reserve interest rate cuts following stronger-than-anticipated economic data.Trump revealed plans to levy a 100% tariff on imported branded pharmaceuticals, 25% on heavy-duty trucks, and 50% on kitchen cabinets. Article Title: US market today: Wall Street slips for a third straight day as tech drags; bond yields rise on growth surprises
Article Text: Wall Street struggled on Thursday, heading toward a rare three-day losing streak as investors digested stronger-than-expected US economic data and corporate results.The S&P 500 fell 0.7% in early trading, marking a deeper decline than the previous two days, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 107 points, or 0.2%, and the Nasdaq composite slid 1%. All three indexes remained close to the record highs set earlier this week, AP reported.Economic reports showed fewer US workers filed for unemployment benefits last week, suggesting layoffs may be slowing. The US economy also grew faster in the spring than previously estimated, and orders for manufactured goods with a relatively long life span exceeded forecasts, adding pressure on expectations for future interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Treasury yields ticked higher, with the 10-year note rising to 4.17% and the two-year yield climbing more sharply.CarMax tumbled 19.1%, the largest loss in the S&P 500, after reporting weaker quarterly profits and fewer vehicle sales compared with last year. Loss projections from past loans also weighed on the stock.Big Tech stocks, which have driven recent market gains, also fell. Nvidia declined 1.8%, Broadcom lost 2.9%, and Alphabet dropped 2.2%, reflecting investor caution about high valuations amid artificial intelligence enthusiasm.Starbucks fluctuated between modest gains and losses after announcing a $1 billion restructuring plan that includes store closures and cutting 900 non-retail jobs, most recently down 0.7%.European markets followed a weaker trend, with Germany’s DAX falling 1% and France’s CAC 0 down 0.7%, after Asia saw a more muted finish.
Article Summary: The S&P 500 fell 0.7% in early trading, marking a deeper decline than the previous two days. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 107 points, or 0.2%, and the Nasdaq composite slid 1%. All three indexes remained close to the record highs set earlier this week.

Article Title: US economy growth: GDP expands at surprising 3.8% pace in April-June quarter; trade shifts drive Q2 upgrade
Article Text: The US economy grew at an unexpected 3.8 per cent annualised pace in the second quarter, significantly higher than the previously estimated 3.3 per cent, government data showed Thursday. The revision highlights a strong rebound from a first-quarter contraction of 0.6 per cent and underscores the influence of shifting trade patterns on the country’s economic performance.Imports, which surged earlier in the year as businesses rushed to beat tariff deadlines, fell by 29.3% in the second quarter, AP reported. The drop added more than five percentage points to GDP, the department noted. Consumer spending also accelerated, rising at a 2.5% pace compared with 0.6% in the first quarter.The Trump administration has imposed double-digit tariffs on imports ranging from steel and aluminum to autos, a move the president argues protects US industry and offsets the cost of his sweeping tax cuts. “With tariffs, we are bringing factories back and making America strong again,” Trump has repeatedly said.But mainstream economists caution the protectionist strategy risks slowing growth and fuelling inflation.They argue tariffs are paid by US importers, who often pass costs to consumers. While inflationary effects have so far been modest, economists warn the unpredictable tariff rollouts have unsettled businesses and dampened hiring.Labour Department data revisions this month showed that 911,000 fewer jobs were created in the year ending March than first reported, pulling the monthly average down to 71,000. Since March, job growth has slowed further, averaging just 53,000 a month.The Fed, seeking to support the labour market, cut its benchmark interest rate last week for the first time since December. The Commerce Department will release its initial July-September GDP estimate on October 30, with economists surveyed by FactSet forecasting growth to slow to 1.5%.
Article Summary: The US economy grew at an unexpected 3.8% annualised pace in the second quarter, significantly higher than the previously estimated 3.3%. The revision highlights a strong rebound from a first-quarter contraction of 0.6% and underscores the influence of shifting trade patterns on the country’s economic performance.

Article Title: Starbucks layoffs: Coffee giant to close US and Canada stores, cut 900 jobs in turnaround push
Article Text: Starbucks is laying off around 900 non-retail employees and shutting some stores in the US and Canada as part of a broader turnaround strategy, the company announced on Thursday. Employees who are being eliminated will be informed early Friday, while the closures will be rolled out in the coming days.The Seattle-based coffee chain said a review of its North American locations showed many outlets were underperforming financially or not meeting customer expectations. “Each year, we open and close coffeehouses for a variety of reasons, from financial performance to lease expirations. This is a more significant action that we understand will impact partners and customers. Our coffeehouses are centers of the community, and closing any location is difficult,” Starbucks CEO Brian Niccol wrote in a letter to staff, as quoted by AP.Following the move, Starbucks expects to end its fiscal year with 18,300 stores in North America, down 124 from last year. It is unusual for the company to reduce its store count within a fiscal year.Niccol, a turnaround specialist brought in a year ago to revive Starbucks, previously led Chipotle through a dramatic recovery. During his six-year tenure there, the brand doubled its revenue and profit while its stock price soared.Starbucks said it will offer severance and support packages to employees affected by the layoffs.
Article Summary: Starbucks is laying off around 900 non-retail employees and shutting some stores in the US and Canada. The Seattle-based coffee chain said a review of its North American locations showed many outlets were underperforming financially or not meeting customer expectations. Starbucks expects to end its fiscal year with 18,300 stores in North America, down 124 from last year.

Article Title: Asian shares take a breather: Japanese Yen weakens sharply; Brent and WTI crude prices fall after overnight spike

Asian market performance



Foreign exchange markets



Commodities







Asian shares paused their recent rally on Thursday as investors positioned for month- and quarter-end flows, while the Japanese yen weakened to fresh lows against the euro and the Swiss franc surged amid currency market volatility.Oil prices slipped after climbing over 2% overnight to seven-week highs, following a surprise drop in US crude inventories that raised supply concerns amid export issues in Iraq, Venezuela, and Russia.S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures edged up 0.1% ahead of remarks from Federal Reserve officials, which investors will watch closely for guidance on interest rates.San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly said further rate cuts will likely be needed, though the timing remains uncertain.
